items.content_html: I realise that #3755 only removed hidden text in <div> elements. This PR does the same thing for <p> elements. See #3694 for the rationale here.

items.content_html:
Bumps actions/github-script from v3 to v4.0.1.

Release notes

Sourced from actions/github-script's releases.

Fix "require" search path

Previously, the wrapped require searched the existing module.paths and then process.cwd(). We now only search process.cwd(). See actions/github-script#136 for details.

Commits
  • 85e88a6 Merge pull request #136 from actions/search-cwd-first
  • 5cbb702 v4.0.1
  • 1ef7fd0 Remove require search fallback
  • a49bf6b Search the cwd first, then existing module paths
  • 95fb649 Merge pull request #135 from actions/wrap-require
  • 2923e50 Run build script
  • b616178 Merge branch 'wrap-require' of https://github.com/actions/github-script into ...
  • c758586 v4.0.0
  • 256da4e Update src/wrap-require.ts
  • 5ee517d Workflow syntax error
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

Dependabot will resolve any conflicts with this PR as long as you don't alter it yourself. You can also trigger a rebase manually by commenting @dependabot rebase.

Dependabot commands and options

You can trigger Dependabot actions by commenting on this PR:

  • @dependabot rebase will rebase this PR
  • @dependabot recreate will recreate this PR, overwriting any edits that have been made to it
  • @dependabot merge will merge this PR after your CI passes on it
  • @dependabot squash and merge will squash and merge this PR after your CI passes on it
  • @dependabot cancel merge will cancel a previously requested merge and block automerging
  • @dependabot reopen will reopen this PR if it is closed
  • @dependabot close will close this PR and stop Dependabot recreating it. You can achieve the same result by closing it manually
  • @dependabot ignore this major version will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this major version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself)
  • @dependabot ignore this minor version will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this minor version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself)
  • @dependabot ignore this dependency will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this dependency (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself)
items.title: chore(deps): bump actions/github-script from v3 to v4.0.1

items.content_html:
Added a page about this interface. And this page is needed for #4234 .
Still, the same problem as the parent doc: it seems the backend didn't recognize the correct specification url, it should be: https://wicg.github.io/webhid/ .
items.title: HID interface page

items.content_html:
This PR updates the "MDN Markdown" spec to talk about representing notes, warnings, and what I'm awkwardly calling "callouts", based on conversations in #3483 and #3927.

I'm choosing option 2 from #3483 as the authoring format, where you use a blockquote and a magic word at the start of the content, and asking this to be converted to the <div class="thing"> syntax in the output (and I think in the internal representation, although I haven't specified that here, and perhaps I should).
items.title: Specify Markdown note syntax

items.content_html:
Redo of a PR that got into a muddle (#3707)

  1. Moves the non-standard :-moz-ui-valid to :user-valid
  2. Updates that page to be correct as to the spec, adds an example
  3. Updates user-invalid as it still referred to the moz property it was moved from
  4. Adds an example to user-invalid

Fixes: #4304
Fixes: #4310

@chrisdavidmills here is the redo for user-valid, I think these ones where things get moved are way more likely to get into a muddle so if we can merge it before it happens again would be good :D
items.title: fixing user-valid pseudo

items.content_html:
What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)

Over in BCD, we're inclined to drop Accept-Charset. Browsers haven't sent this header for many, many years (IE since 2008, Chrome since 2013). After giving it some thought, I think mentioning in this decade confuses more than informs. Some text I removed makes a pretty good case for me:

With UTF-8 now being well-supported, being the preferred way of encoding characters, and to guarantee better privacy through less configuration-based entropy, browsers omit the Accept-Charset header: Internet Explorer 8, Safari 5, Opera 11, Firefox 10 and Chrome 27 have abandoned this header.

Nobody ought to send this header, servers ought to ignore it, and it's interesting mostly as a historic artifact. This PR scrubs most mentions of the header (except as one of the forbidden header names) and deletes the reference page.

MDN URL of main page changed

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Accept-Charset
items.title: Remove mentions of historic `Accept-Charset` header

items.content_html:
Add a page for WebHID API. Later I will add pull requests one by one for the global interfaces HID, HIDConnectionEvent, HIDInputReportEvent, HIDDevice.

As for compat data, already added a pull request: mdn/browser-compat-data#9910

And it seems the backend didn't recognize the correct specification url, it should be: https://wicg.github.io/webhid/ . So maybe ur backend developers should work to fix that recognization problem?

To-do list about associated pages: (I think maybe I'll do them one by one in future PRs, it's not recommended to make a substantial PR)

  • navigator.hid - #4345
  • interface pages
    • HID - #4368
    • HIDConnectionEvent
    • HIDInputReportEvent
    • HIDConnectionEvent
items.title: Add a page for WebHID API

items.content_html:
If we’re going to mention CSRF in the CORS article, we would need to say quite a lot more than what this note says. And since this note is wrongly saying that you don’t need to worry at all about CSRF in a specific subset of cases (simple requests), it may give the very wrong impression that CORS overall doesn’t create any additional CSRF risk.

So it’s better to mention nothing at all about CSRF in this CORS article than it is to have this one mention in this one odd note.

Fixes #4111
items.title: Drop unhelpful note about CSRF from CORS doc
